Body: This is a somewhat conceptual question. I know that other limits (i.e. like memory limit the number apps installed much more).QuestionAccording to the security guide of android.com sandboxing (and security) of apps relies on underlying linux' user ids. Those are said to be stored as 32bit and since root takes away the value 0, there should be the 4,294,967,295 other unique ids, and hence "slots" for apps, right?The purpose of this answer is to seek a response either confirm or refute the suggestion I made, i.e. that apps and UIDs relate?   Potentially this could be Android Version dependent, as I expect that selinux might be able to help sandboxing without using the "only 32bit" UID limitation, right?
Title: Is 4,294,967,295 the conceptual limit of apps installable to a android device?

history.Text: This is a somewhat conceptual question. I know that other limits (i.e. like memory limit the number apps installed much more).#Question#According to the [security guide of android.com][1] sandboxing (and security) of apps relies on underlying [linux' user ids][2]. Those are said to be stored as 32bit and since `root` takes away the value `0`, there should be the `4,294,967,295` other unique ids, and hence "slots" for apps, right?The purpose of this answer is to seek a response either confirm or refute the suggestion I made, i.e. that apps and `UIDs` relate?   Potentially this could be Android Version dependent, as I expect that `selinux` might be able to help `sandboxing` without using the "only 32bit" UID limitation, right?  [1]: https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/security/permissions.html#userid  [2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_identifier#Type
Is 4,294,967,295 the conceptual limit of apps installable to a android device?
